Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 02:18PM stephN wrote: I had an excisional biopsy also.  I had a core needle biopsy, but when I got to my appt with the surgeon (the same day) he had been on the phone with the radiologist who had told him that it was suspicious enough looking on film and u/s that she felt like the area needed to be taken out regardless so he had already put my surgery on his schedule when he came in to talk to me. Turns out they were right. Oh, and I'm premenopausal too.  ;o)  Good luck!!
Posts.Title: Still not diagnosed, but surgeon wants a lumpectomy claireinaz claireinaz

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2011 09:51AM stephN wrote: Hi lamom, I hesitate to give advice because everyone has such different experiences.  One thing to remember is that most people on these boards have cancer--the ones whose tests came back benign don't usually stick around.  So, I think you'll find that the people here tend to be more proactive about tests and such. That said, I had a similar experience to yours.  I felt a lump and went to my gyno.  At the imaging center where I went, the radiologist said it was fine.  But since I felt a lump, my gynecologist referred me to a breast specialist.  I had my films sent to a nationally recognized hospital and then went to their breast health center.  It turned out I did have early stage breast cancer.   So, I would suggest a second opinion, if only for your peace of mind.  It's probably benign--most are--but, in my opinion, it's always better to be sure!
Posts.Title: Negative Ultrasound, but still feel Lump lamom318 Deborah12345678

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2012 09:54PM stephN wrote: Beacon gave you the best advice!  Stay off of google unless you have something specific to google.  You'll have yourselff convinced of all kinds of horrors!  You are in the hardest part, the not knowing and waiting.  You'll know something concrete soon.  Hugs, Steph
Posts.Title: scared!!! sandik marie5890

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 05:33AM stephN wrote: Hey y'all, I had a horrible headache and neckache the whole time I was in radiation, so much so that the RO ordered an MRI to rule out mets.  The headache went away after I took muscle relaxers for ten days and as soon as I switched to boosts, the neckache went away.  It was the position that I was in for treatment and the tension of it all.   I don't know if that's the case for everyone, but it was the case for me!   (((hugs!!)))
Posts.Title: Radiation and headaches capers10 stephN

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 05:00PM stephN wrote: Hey!  I'm so glad you started this thread.  I've been on the same journey.  It's such a hard thing to research and you really have to look at the ingredients because so many things that say natural still have chemicals in them that are better to avoid.  I love Tarte cosmetics too, especially for eyeliner and mascara.  I'm using Mineral Fusion for foundation, but I got it at Earth Fare.  I've given up on finding a lipstick I can wear.  I'm allergic to everything.  I use a lip balm from Alba. As far as household stuff goes, there are tons of recipes online for safe stuff.  I was really hesitant about doing it, but it's so easy.  Most things are made with Dr. Bronner's castile soap, Arm and Hammer Washing Powder, Borax, and/or Vinegar.  Things that have been around for years.  I even made some deodorant with coconut oil, baking soda and cornstarch.  It works great.  I NEVER would've dreamed that I would do that and like it.  I guess after stinking my way through radiation I'm just happy not to smell!  (PM me if you want some resources for more info on recipes and stuff) I sent an email to Toms the other day because I bought some toothpast that says Natural on it but it has sodium lauryl sulfate in it.  That makes me really mad.  They informed me that it's made from plant products and therefore safe.  Since I don't believe them, I guess I'll either pay more for their one toothpaste that doesn't have SLS in it or find another kind. Hair products have been the hardest for me to find.  I'm using Alba Botanicals right now.  It does have a pretty strong fragrance and some stuff I can't pronounce in it, but I'm desperate. I tried the Dr. Bronner's and my hair was horrible.  I have dry, super curly hair and it's really picky.  I think I might try California Baby. I'm going to check out Neutrogena Naturals for a moisturizer.  I haven't been able to find one for day.  I use coconut oil for night, but it's kinda greasy for under makeup. Thanks for the recs, y'all!
Posts.Title: Better cosmetic & household products? StacyRose stephN

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2012 12:34AM stephN wrote: Hi there!  I was just your age and in your situation when I was diagnosed last summer.  My radiologist said something different than Ann's.  She didn't say it was cancer but she said, it doesn't matter what the biopsy says it is, we're taking it all out because of the way it looks on the film and in the ultrasound.  My pathology took five days to come back the first time, but my surgery was scheduled from the first day when I went for the diagnostic mammogram and visit with the surgeon.  It's all so scary and unknown at the stage where you are and there's so much on the internet that makes it worse.  However, most people do get benign results, so keep reminding yourself of that!  Good luck!  I hope your appointment goes well and you get really good results!
Posts.Title: 42 with questions Mindyandgang mishka

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2012 06:03AM stephN wrote: NoMore, also you should keep asking for help until someone listens.  I had docs who were willing to give me anti-depressants, but don't let the fact that yours aren't stop you from getting the help you need.  I started Effexor during rads and it made a HUGE difference.  I didn't know how depressed I was...I thought it was fatigue.  It was only partly fatigue.   The other thing I would suggest and this might just be me...someone else might think I'm totally off here...but I would get rid of the cds and podcasts and self-help books and all that stuff.  To me, those just remind me that I have cancer (althought I am NED and expect to stay this way!)  What has helped me the most is to get back to my normal life, doing normal things.  Now, my life isn't anything like it was before.  We moved to a new state a week before I was diagnosed, so even my normal isn't the normal it was BC, but I'm enjoying going to my kids' games and plays and going to church and all the things that if I did them in the fall, I felt horrible.   Like beacon800 said, you are doing the right things...give yourself time.  Understand that you aren't on anyone's schedule for recovery but your own.  And make the doctors listen to you.  If your PCP won't listen, get another one, or go to a psychiatrist.  You deserve to feel good.  Love and hugs, sweet friend.
Posts.Title: Running out of places to turn to for help NoMoreHL karen333

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 05:28PM - edited Feb 3, 2012 05:28PM by stephN Hi Kristen,  Her2+ isn't bad per se.  It is an aggressive cancer marker, but along with chemo, there is a drug called Herceptin which is very effective in fighting Her2+ breast cancer. Fear is the worst.  It's debilitating.  I'm with Shirlann.  Take the valium.  Is there ever going to be a time in your life that you think might be more appropriate than this to take it?  ;o)  My doctor prescribed it and told me it was a muscle relaxer, which I guess in a sense, it is.  I was so knotted up from tension that I could barely turn my head.   ((((Big hugs))))  You will get through this.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed and scared kfontaine bluepearl

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2012 11:56PM stephN wrote: I had my period while I got one of my lumpectomies.   I kept a tampon in.  I just told everyone matter of factly that I had my period and I had a tampon in.  No one seemed to question it. More embarassing was when I was on my period during my last CT scan.  (It was also my last period b/c I had a total hysterectomy five days later).   I got the printout from the radiologist report.  There in black and white it says, "There is a tampon in the vaginal canal."  Yes, thank you, now for all posterity, it is in my medical record.
Posts.Title: Embarassing question.... Emaline jocelynlally

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 01:54PM stephN wrote: Breast cancer complicates everything, I have learned.  All those hormones work together.  Anyway, I'm 43 and had my ovaries out in December.  I didn't really mourn the loss of my ovaries, but dealing with instant menopause is kind of a pain. I was prepared for it, so I wasn't surprised by it, but it's something to think about.   Teri, I'm really sorry that you're having to deal with this, but you will get through it.  It seems like so much, and it is.  But I was diagnosed in July, 2011.  I thought things would never be the same, and they aren't, but I am starting to fairly normal again.  You'll get through this to the other side. Steph
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed...what about ovaries TeriR Deirdre1

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2011 05:10AM stephN wrote: I was really scared too.  It helped when I finally fessed up to my techs.  They were very reassuring and caring.   It also helped the first couple of weeks to have music on my iPod that helped me not think about the radiation.  After the first few weeks, I didn't need it any more. Good luck!  It really does go by fast. Steph
Posts.Title: Things that helped me during radiation eileenr56 Mandalala

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2012 11:04PM stephN wrote: Hi kingjr,  I couldn't take tamoxifen because of the risk of uterine cancer.  (I had  a pre-exisiting condition.)  I opted for the full hysterectomy/oophorectomy and AI also, but it's a very personal decision.  I didn't want to take the Zoladex or Lupron shots.  If I had been closer to menopause, I might've tried that for awhile.  I do feel great in menopause, though, despite the hot flashes! Steph
Posts.Title: Can't take Tamoxifen kingjr66 hhillmontana

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 07:14AM - edited Mar 4, 2012 07:15AM by stephN Hi Kelley, My lump could easily be felt but was just a cluster of microcalcifications on mammo.  When they went to biopsy it, it disappeared completely when they administered the lidocaine (or whatever they use to numb it).  It just looked like a blur on the screen.  The radiologist told me that she took more samples than usual and she knew the general area.  She felt like she got it, but she warned me that the results might not be reliable.  She actually did get it, though.   Hope that helps! Steph
